_header: O High Empress and queen celestial
Subjects: ballads, religious; Virgin Mary, songs in honour of
_description: ‘Ane Ballat of Our Lady’, attributed to William Dunbar—six 8-line stanzas

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
O hie Emperice and quene celestiall Princes eterne and flour
                    Immaculate…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…In euery place blissit mote ȝe be Eternaly abufe all
                    erdly wicht
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.
BodArcSelB24.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1939: 26-8.
Saupe,  Karen,
                        ed.  
             Middle English Marian
                    Lyrics.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 1998: 161-2; 273-4.

Asloan.First Lines:
O hie emprys and quene celestiale Princis eterne and flour
                    Immaculat…
Asloan.Last Lines:
…Incomperable þe haly gast als fast In to ȝour
                    Innocens dovne has sent
Asloan.Note:
5 stanzas; a post-medieval transcript is Edinburgh, University Library
                    La.IV.27-28, item 6; ed. Laing (1834)
XLaing,  David. 
             The Poems of William Dunbar.
         2 vols. Edinburgh: Laing and Forbes, 1834; Supplement, 1865, 1 (suppl.),
                    305.
Asloan.Attributed Title: ‘heir followis ane ballat of our lady’ (f. 292)
Asloan.Editions:
Craigie,  William Alexander. 
             The Asloan Manuscript.
             2 vols. 
             Scottish Text Society
         n.s. 14, 16. Edinburgh, London: Blackwood, 1923, 192: 2.245-6.
